## What is Climate Risk?

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    **Climate risk** is the potential for adverse consequences for human and ecological systems, arising from the interaction of **climate-related hazards** with the **exposure** and **vulnerability** of people, ecosystems, and their biodiversity.
  </blockquote>
</div>


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="32.5%"}

::: fragment
<div style="text-align: center; width: 100%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/ipcc-risk-propeller-minimal.jpg"
       style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold; font-size:1.25rem;">Source: IPCC (2022)</p>
</div>

:::

:::
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

- Climate risk is **not just** about how big the storm or flood is.
- It comes from **three ingredients**:
  - **Climate Hazard** ‚Äì the physical climate event (heat waves, droughts, floods, storms)
  - **Exposure** ‚Äì who/what is in harm‚Äôs way
  - **Vulnerability** ‚Äì how fragile or resilient society and ecosystems are

:::
::::

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

::: fragment

In shorthand we can think of:
<div style="display:block; margin:-35px;"></div>

$$ 
\boxed{\color{purple}{(\textbf{Climate Risk})} \;\propto\; \color{#1f77b4}{(\textbf{Climate Hazard})} \times \color{#17becf}{(\textbf{Exposure})} \times \color{#E69F00}{(\textbf{Vulnerability})}}
$$
:::

<!-- - Under **risk**, outcomes are **uncertain**, but we can assign **probabilities** to different possible outcomes. -->

# üåßÔ∏è‚ö° Cost Benefit Analysis under Uncertainty {background-color="#1c4982"}

##  Cost‚ÄìBenefit Analysis under Uncertainty 

:::callout-note
## What is Risk in Economics?
- Under **risk**, outcomes are **uncertain**, but we can assign **probabilities** to different possible outcomes.
:::

- Many real-world **policy projects** have uncertain outcomes:
  - **Dams and flood-control projects** (risk of catastrophic failure or being overtopped)
  - **Urban drainage and stormwater systems** (may be underdesigned for future intense rainfall)
  - **Drought adaptation in agriculture** (e.g., new irrigation systems or drought-tolerant crops may underperform under future climate)
  
- A robust **Cost‚ÄìBenefit Analysis (CBA)** must account for:
  - The **range of possible outcomes**, and  
  - **How likely** each outcome is.


<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- CBA under risk asks:   -->
<!-- > *What is the project‚Äôs **expected net benefit**, given different possible futures and their probabilities?* -->
<!-- ::: -->




##  üìê Incorporating Risk into CBA: Expected Value

Suppose a project can lead to three different outcomes $x_i$, where $i = 1,2,3$:

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment
- Each outcome $x_i$ has:
  - Probability $P(x_i)$
  - Net benefit $NB(x_i)$ 
  
:::
:::


::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment
- For a **single** outcome:
  $$E[NB(x_i)] = P(x_i)\times NB(x_i)$$

:::
:::
::::

::: fragment
- For **all** possible outcomes, the **expected net benefit** of the project is:
  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  E[NB(X)] &= \sum_{i=1}^3 \bigl[ P(x_i)\times NB(x_i) \bigr]\\
  &= P(x_1)\times NB(x_1) \,+\,P(x_2)\times NB(x_2) \,+\,P(x_3)\times NB(x_3)
  \end{aligned}
  $$
:::

<div style="display:block; margin:-25px;"></div>

- We use this as a summary measure of **what the project delivers on average**, given the possible outcomes and their probabilities.


## üåäüèóÔ∏è CBA on Dam for Flood Control 

- Proposal: build a **dam** for flood control.
  - Construction cost: **\$7 million**.
  - Benefits depend on **future precipitation** (and resulting flood risk).

<span class="fragment">
<div style="font-size: 0.75em; width: 90%; margin: 0 auto;">

<hr style="margin-bottom: 0.3em;">

| Scenario                                     | Net Benefit $NB(x_i)$ | Probability $P(x_i)$ | Expected Value $P(x_i)\times NB(x_i)$ |
|---------------------------------------------|-----------------------|----------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Low precipitation                           | \$5 million           | $0.27$               | \$1.35 million                         |
| Average precipitation                       | \$10 million          | $0.49$               | \$4.90 million                         |
| High precipitation                          | \$20 million          | $0.23$               | \$4.60 million                         |
| Extremely high precipitation (dam fails)    | $-\$100$ million      | $0.01$               | $-\$1.00$ million                      |
<hr style="margin-bottom: 0.3em;">

</div>              
</span>
<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

- **Expected net benefit** of the project:
<div style="display:block; margin:-20px;"></div>

  $$E[NB(X)] \approx \$9.85\text{ million}$$

<div style="display:block; margin:-40px;"></div>
- Would CBA recommend building the dam?


## Risk Aversion

Imagine you must choose **one** option:

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment
- **Option A:** Receive **\$50** for sure.  

- **Option B:** Toss a coin:  
  - Heads ‚Üí **\$100**   
  - Tails ‚Üí **\$0**

:::
:::


::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment
- The **expected value** of both options is:  

  $$EV = 0.5\times \$100 + 0.5\times \$0 = \$50$$

:::

:::
::::



- Your **risk preference** can be categorized as:
  - **Risk-averse** ‚Üí prefers A (safe \$50).  
  - **Risk-loving** ‚Üí prefers B (chance at \$100).  
  - **Risk-neutral** ‚Üí indifferent (cares only about EV).




## üò¨ Risk Aversion: Why Expected Value Isn‚Äôt Everything

<div style="display:block; margin:-25px;"></div>

Imagine you must choose **one** option:


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment
- **Option A:** Receive **\$100** for sure.  
- **Option B:** $50\%$ chance of **+\$300**, and $50\%$ chance of **‚Äì\$100**.


:::
:::


::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment

<div style="display:block; margin:-25px;"></div>
The **expected value** of both options:  

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

$$
\begin{aligned}
EV(B) &= 0.5\times \$300 + 0.5\times (-\$100) \\
&= \$150 - \$50 = \$100
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

:::
::::


- Expected value treats **gains and losses symmetrically**, weighted by probabilities.
- But many people are **risk averse**:
  - They dislike **small chances of large losses**, even if the EV looks attractive.

- In expected value terms, **A and B are equal** ($EV = \$100$),  
  but many people still pick **A** ‚Üí evidence of **risk aversion**.



## üé≤‚ùì Risk vs. Uncertainty (Economist‚Äôs Definitions)


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment
### Risk
- Variability or randomness that can be **quantified**.  
- We can list possible outcomes and attach **probabilities** we trust.
- <u>Example</u>:
  - A **$1$-in-$1,000$** chance of a nuclear accident over the plant‚Äôs life.
  - A **$1$-in-$5,000$** chance of a major offshore oil spill.
  - Health risks of smoking estimated from statistical data.

:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment
### Uncertainty
- Variability or randomness that **cannot be reliably quantified**.
- <u>Example</u>: extreme, poorly understood climate outcomes:
  - Massive methane release from thawing permafrost,
  - Large shifts in ocean currents (e.g., weakening of the Gulf Stream).

:::
:::
::::

<!-- ::: callout-important -->
<!-- In **risk**, we think we know the probabilities.   -->
<!-- In **uncertainty**, we don‚Äôt. -->
<!-- ::: -->


## üö® Uncertainty & the Precautionary Principle

<div style="display:block; margin:-5px;"></div>

::: fragment
::: {.callout-important}
### Precautionary Principle & Safe Minimum Standards

When potential impacts are **large, irreversible, and deeply uncertain**, economists and policymakers often argue for a **precautionary principle** or a **safe minimum standard**, rather than relying only on expected value.
:::
:::

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

- <u>**Precautionary principle**</u>:  
  Policies should account for uncertainty by taking steps to **avoid low-probability but catastrophic events**.

- <u>**Safe minimum standard**</u>:  
  Set environmental policies so as to **avoid possible catastrophic consequences**.



- In the **dam example**:
  - A **1% chance** of catastrophic failure barely changes $E[NB]$,
  - but for people downstream, even a **small chance of huge damages** may be unacceptable.

## üåß Flood Insurance Choices ‚Äì ScenarioÔ∏è

Imagine you own a **house next to a river**.

- Each year, there is a **10% chance** of a major flood.
- If a flood hits, your house suffers **\$100,000** in damage.

<span class="fragment">You are considering three options:</span>

1. **No insurance**
2. **Partial, subsidized insurance**
3. **Full, risk-based insurance**


## üßÆ Flood Insurance Choices ‚Äì The Options

**Flood probability:** $10\%$ per year  
**Damage if flood:** \$100,000  

$$
(\text{Expected annual loss if uninsured}) = 0.10 \times 100,000 = \$10,000.
$$

::: fragment
Here are your choices:

| Option | Annual Premium | You Pay If Flood | Description                                  |
|--------|----------------|------------------|----------------------------------------------|
| A      | \$0            | \$100,000        | No Insurance         |
| B      | \$500          | \$30,000         | Partial Insurance (substantial loss remains)    |
| C      | \$2,000        | \$1,000          | Full Insurance (tiny deductible)       |

:::

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

<span class="fragment">**Question:** Which option would *you* choose?</span>

## From NFIP Problems to Economic Incentives

<!-- **Key question:**   -->

<div style="font-size:2rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    When we insure people against flood losses, do we unintentionally encourage them to **take more risk**?
  </blockquote>
</div>


- Cheap or subsidized insurance can:
  - Make it more attractive to **stay in high-risk areas**.
  - Make **rebuilding in the same risky spot** more likely.
- This brings us to the central concept: **moral hazard**.

:::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-note style="font-size: 2rem;"}
### Moral Hazard

<div style="font-size: 1.75rem;">
**Moral hazard** occurs when having insurance causes people to **change their behavior**, taking **more risk** because they do **not bear the full cost** of bad outcomes.
</div>
:::
::::

- Example: One home flooded **40 times**, receiving **$428,379** in payments.



## How FEMA Is Addressing Moral Hazard in NFIP
<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

**FEMA has already implemented several key reforms:**

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
- **Risk-based pricing ([Risk Rating 2.0](https://www.fema.gov/sites/default/files/documents/fema_rr-2.0_04-2025.pdf))** ‚Äì Premiums now reflect:
  - Distance to water  
  - Flood frequency  
  - Elevation  
- **Mitigation incentives** ‚Äì Premium discounts for:
  - Elevation  
  - Floodproofing  
  - Compliance with updated building standards  
    
:::


::: {.column width="50%"}
- **Repeated-loss controls**
  - Coverage limits and mitigation requirements after multiple claims.
- **Community Rating System (CRS)**
  - Better floodplain management 
    (zoning, building codes, drainage, 
    <span class="levee-tooltip">
      _levees_
      <span class="levee-popup">
        <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/flood-levee.jpg" alt="Levee example" style="max-width:180px;">
      </span>
    </span>, and other protective measures)
    ‚áí lower premiums for all residents.
  - Over 1,500 participating communities.

<!-- *These tools are designed to strengthen the link between **risk, price, and behavior**.* -->

:::
::::

## Why Incentives Are Still Weakened
<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

**Despite reforms, pricing still does not fully reflect true flood risk due to:**

- **Political pressures**
  - Resistance to sharp premium increases in high-risk districts.
  - Rate caps and delayed adjustments weaken price signals.
- **Affordability concerns**
  - Fully risk-based premiums can be difficult for low- and middle-income households.
  - Subsidies and caps soften the link between risk and price.
- **Legacy underpricing & grandfathering**
  - Many older properties still pay premiums based on outdated, lower-risk conditions.
  - Similar-risk homes can face very different insurance prices.

<!-- **Bottom line:** -->
<!-- FEMA‚Äôs reforms move incentives in the right direction, but **pricing still does not fully reflect true flood risk for all properties**, limiting the program‚Äôs ability to fully control moral hazard. -->

## Underinsurance Despite High Flood Risk

- Moral hazard predicts **too much risk-taking** when people are insured.
- **Yet in practice**, the dominant problem in flood insurance markets is the opposite: **underinsurance.**
  - Only about **49%** of residents in high-risk flood zones purchase flood insurance.

- This low take-up is explained by several factors:
  - **Affordability** of coverage
  - **Limited understanding** of insurance
  - **Misperceptions of federal disaster aid**
  - **Incomplete or unclear risk information**

- In addition, **systematic behavioral biases** strongly shape how homeowners perceive and respond to flood risk.




## 1. Myopia (Present Bias) in Flood Risk Perception

<div style="display:block; margin:15px;"></div>

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
<div style="text-align: center; width: 100%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/flood-myopia.jpg" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -30px; margin-top: -30px;">
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: nonincremental

- **Myopia (Present Bias):**  
  Tendency to focus on immediate costs and heavily discount future benefits.  
  - Up-front premium feels large; future flood loss feels distant.
:::
:::
::::


## 2. Optimism in Flood Risk Perception

</div>

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: nonincremental
- **Optimism:**  
  Tendency to underestimate the likelihood of future losses.  
  - Homeowners believe flooding is unlikely to happen to them.

## How FEMA Is Addressing Underinsurance in NFIP?
<div style="display:block; margin:-18px;"></div>

**FEMA has implemented several key *choice-architecture tools* and behavioral policy features:**

<div style="display:block; margin:-8px;"></div>

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

::: fragment

<div style="display:block; margin:-25px;"></div>

**Automatic insurance through mortgages**  

- Flood insurance is **mandatory by default** for many federally backed mortgages in high-risk zones.
- This already functions as a **default enrollment mechanism** for some households.

:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
- **Risk communication improvements** ‚Äì FEMA provides:
  - [Flood maps](https://msc.fema.gov/nfhl)  
  - Property-level flood risk estimates
- **Premium _signaling_ under Risk Rating 2.0** strengthens the **salience of risk through price**.
- **Post-disaster outreach:** Increased insurance marketing and rebuilding guidance after major floods.

:::
::::

## Why Does Underinsurance Persist in the NFIP?
<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

- **No universal default enrollment**
  - Households outside mortgage requirements are not **actively opt in**.
- **Weak default framing**
  - Flood insurance is treated as an **optional add-on**, not a standard form of protection.

- **Limited behavioral nudges**
  - **Lack of simple tools** that express risk in dollar terms or provide reminders at key disaster-related housing decisions

- **Complex information environment**
  - Flood maps and insurance rules are **technically accurate but cognitively demanding**.

<div style="display:block; margin:-30px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    FEMA relies mainly on **voluntary purchase** and **information disclosure**, which are often insufficient when **myopia, optimism, and inertia** are present.
  </blockquote>
</div>

## üìàüåßÔ∏è Why Are NFIP Costs & Debt Rising? ‚Äî Revisited
<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

Beyond climate hazard, exposure, and vulnerability, **insurance behavior and policy further amplify NFIP losses**:

- **Moral hazard**, concentrated in a **small subset of repetitive-loss properties**, keeps the riskiest structures in place.
- **Underinsurance shrinks the risk pool**, so premium revenue is **too low to absorb catastrophic losses**.
- Reliance on **post-disaster aid rather than insurance** weakens incentives to relocate, mitigate, or reform land-use policy‚Äîkeeping **exposure and vulnerability high over time**.

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.9rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    Rising NFIP losses reflect a **system-wide interaction of climate change, development patterns, and insurance design** ‚Äî not just by the choices of individual homeowners.
  </blockquote>
</div>
